Participants.evidence: PATIENTS: A total of 55 consecutive patients (>18 years) undergoing elective laryngeal surgery were assessed for participation, providing 40 evaluable data sets with 20 per group.

Intervention.evidence: INTERVENTIONS: Random allocation to intubation with Tritube and ventilation with FCV (Tritube–FCV group) or intubation with MLT 6.0 and ventilation with VCV (MLT–VCV) as control.

Objective.evidence: OBJECTIVES: We hypothesised that a Tritube with FCV would provide better laryngeal visibility and surgical conditions for laryngeal surgery than a conventional microlaryngeal tube (MLT) with volume-controlled ventilation (VCV).

Method_Outcome.evidence: MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Primary endpoint was the tube-related concealment of laryngeal structures, measured on videolaryngoscopic photographs by appropriate software.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: INTERVENTIONS: Random allocation to intubation with Tritube and ventilation with FCV (Tritube–FCV group) or intubation with MLT 6.0 and ventilation with VCV (MLT–VCV) as control.

Result_Outcome.evidence: RESULTS: There was less concealment of laryngeal structures with the Tritube than with the MLT; 7 [6 to 9] vs. 22 [18 to 27] %, ( P < 0.001).
